FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Youtube Guides:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YQjAIlFZWWc&t=790s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Dj9gTiLHf8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7BMnGi8yxTQ

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

Astral Librarian Edition
FAQ:
>Can anyone have an out of body experience?
Yes, this is a natural part of being human that has been mostly forgotten.

>Is it not just a vivid lucid dream?
No. A successful astral projection feels just as, often even more real than the waking reality you're experiencing right now.

>Does it have to be difficult and take me months or more to attain this ability?
No, the only barrier is your mind - both conscious and subconscious. If you think it's going to be difficult, it will. Many people can be successful within their first few tries. Fear can hold you back.

>Do I have to come back from shifting?
No.

>Is Astral Projection Dangerous?
The only way it can be dangerous is if you believe it to be, and even then only to your mental state. You cannot be physically harmed.

threads.com:
How do I do Active Imagination properly?
I'm looking for a method to tangibly help me improve my life, untangle my issues, allow me to know myself better and become my best self, basically "individuate" as Jung said.

Any suggestions?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33529122
>it's just that I have a lot of issues and am not sure where to start. The waters are murky and I'm bad at figuring myself out

What you're doing, or beginning, is not a one and done thing. You'll be doing this for the rest of your life. You are going to cultivate awareness. So don't worry about where to start or what to do. When you start you find the way naturally.

The Power of Now was helpful for me, as was Tolle's videos on cultivating awareness and being here now. This is a practice you will need if you start delving into your imagination because you will need awareness and no distractions of thoughts or judgements, just a curious, present spirit.

One thing you can start in your journal is just typing up your desires and intents. These are the starting points for all things, really, all journeys and quests, stories and myths, all living and dead processes. Why do you journal? What do you intend to do with it?
You can read the books and start taking notes on them there too. What is interesting? What seems significant and why? Do you not like some of it? Why?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33529159
My goal is pretty clear from the start, I'm aware of why I'm doing this. The process might be a lifelong one, but I'm also expecting specific results, which is why I brought up Jung's active imagination in the OP, I was thinking that method was particularly relevant.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33529203
Well for active imagination or any imagination techniques the key is to be relaxed but alert. The body has to be relaxed, the awareness has to be alert and present, not drifting into thoughts, but watching what happens. Keyword watching. The imaginary beings must act without coercion or force. If they stand still then so be it. Wait. They'll do something eventually. Relaxed body, alert mind, and a curious calm and present spirit. That is how you tap into the imagination.
It's also worth reading about the imagination. The Lachmann book is a good history of it. Catafalque will deepen your understanding of Jung and his own efforts to individuate (as well as showing what that really means).

Chances are, that if you're asking questions about it, it probably won't happen. Most of the time these kinds of accomplishments are made by individuals with genius or some innate quality that makes them create a masterpiece.

But i don't think it's impossible to achieve by your own development at all, just more difficult. Two concepts, associative thinking and visualisation. You need to be extraordinarily creative to form genius ideas and you need to see them in your head before you write them. I am certain that Tolkien or H.P Lovecraft could see their creations in their mind. You also need high verbal intelligence and memory, and linguistic capability.

If you're looking for paranormal advice, i'll tell you. A writer is essentially an artist, especially if they write fiction. You might benefit from the help of some god or spirit, or even God or the Monad. Each of these require a different approach. Second you might enchant your self and your ability, or your stories with magic.

Mindset advice; even if you are writing fiction, do not think of it as fiction. Think that you are creating worlds. Even the contents of dreams exist and in some way they are not illusions.

last_replies.com:
Read Writing With Power by Peter Elbow. At the back is a bit about the magic of language you might like. The book has a lot of wisdom in it, and the free writing technique he teaches is powerful and important.

Essentially though you need to live what you write as you write it. This will require you to practice 'presence' or 'awareness'. This should be a full time practice. You are going to meditate your whole life. Be present. No past or future. No thinking. Most of the time you don't need it. When you need to think for some practical thing, pop in and out. Don't think when you don't need to, which is 99% of the time.
Being present, without past or future, is the state you need to be in for you to believe, for you to experience what you write as you write it. Don't focus on the words, focus on the experience you are seeing. The words will come naturally.
Start typing and don't stop. Eventually you will warm up to what you write and start to imagine it as you type it in the moment. Then your writing is alive. When I write, I find there is a period at the start where I am not imagining things, because I haven't built the context yet. But the more I write the closer I get to sinking in, and that's when it lives. That point of sinking usually comes right after the point I feel like there is some resistance, and a desire to stop, that it is worthless. That is the hump and when I type through the doubt I usually forget everything but the dream for an hour or two, and then I look back and I've got a lot of typed up dreaming that seemed to happen outside of time.

While it's commonly associated to the mystic philosophy of Gnosticism (along with Chaos Magick), it can be related towards any significant experience or state of intrinsic knowing regardless of one's spiritual path.

Metanoia is referred to as a "spiritual transformation and change of heart", originating from the Greek "μετάνοια (metanoia) meaning "changing one's mind". Saint Paul the Apostle's mystical experience on the road to Damascus is a notable example of this occurring suddenly.

Who here has achieved Gnosis or undergone Metanoia? If reached, how did you get there? Meditation and contemplation? Being present in the "now"? Something instantaneous without much effort?

I have reason to believe that for several months in 2019 and 2020 the US government or one of its military contractors was testing broad range pheromone distribution "weapons".

As evidence:

In an extremely out of character action, my wife and I wake up at the same time (3 am) on a date in October 2019. We're both out of our minds, red lining for sexual contact and have some of the most aggressive sex we've had in a decade together.

Next day wife is on a walk with two neighbors, the chatty one mentions wild sex in the middle of the night last night. The shy one makes a "huh, wow" face but stops short of saying anything.

I'm at work that same day, Co worker who lives in a subdivision adjacent to ours is groggy and we talk while the coffee brews. Mentions that shits been quiet in the bedroom until 'like two in the morning" when his wife woke him up to fuck and it was wild.

House catches fire weeks later and the repairs are expected to take months. We move across town, 5 miles south of previous residence. 3 am in January 2020 the same thing happens with us.

Neighbor at this address eludes to still active in the bed after 15 years together. Last night middle of the night as evidence.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33527978
The vomeronasal organ, also known as the Jacobson's organ, which affects animal behavior in the presence of pheromones, is basically a vestigial organ in humans.

It's there as a fetus. But then it regresses. It barely picks up anything. And of course, we have large prefrontal cortex that's going to suppress impulsive behavior anyways. It technically works, but it doesn't actually do anything.

While smells do trigger strong memories. It's worth noting that we don't really have words to describe olfactory senses. Unlike, taste, touch, and sight. We simply recognize what a smell comes from. And maybe borrow adjectives associated with other senses. You know, Peaches smell like Peaches. We might even say it smells "sweet".

I've heard that perfume manufactures do have a language of their own. But it takes years to train people to get a sense for it. Outside of crafting aromas, the words are completely useless. It's such an abstract thing.

Basically, he's a deadbeat and you need to give him what he fears most. Responsibility. I don't know how regimented you are in your life, but it would be in your best interest to develop a daily schedule for the home and start tasking his out to do things around the house. He won't want to do it, but it doesn't matter. Write it down any way, but make it fair.

Now this is when it starts getting into the magic part. When ever you see him relaxed, enquire about whether his tasks are complete. Remind him about his tasks that are coming up, but don't get locked into argument simply say you're just reminding him, and don't site examples of when he failed to accomplish his tasks. When he fails to do something mundane like bring the trash to the road, that's when you say "This is why I always remind you". You're examples of his failures should be in the moment.

This is an ancient female magic passed on to them by chickens called "hen-pecking" or tasking. It's extremely effective at driving deadbeats away. I've seen it used in practice to great effect. But it has to be relentless and not malicious.
